remixed_from.author: -Ei9ht-
remixed_from.title: Ei9ht Star Wars Christmas Tree Star remix from Dantesgift

title: Christmas Tree DeathStarDestroyer
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
UPDATE - All files have been re-uploaded as I found a couple of issues with the STLs containing the Interdictor model. There's also now a taller star that uses the Super Star Destroyer model. Finally, the cone that slides over the top of the tree is now 10-sided rather than rounded to match the "Imperial" aesthetic!

I loved the "Ei9ht Star Wars Christmas Tree Star remix from Dantesgift" and, having printed one myself, wanted to make one for a friend. There were a few things I wanted to change though:

  • Some small parts were just too small to print, like the domes on the Imperial Star Destroyers
  • There were quite a few mesh errors, especially on the bottoms of the Interdictor Star Destroyers
  • I'm not a fan of the "Gladiator" Star Destroyers with the two points

I also wanted to learn TinkerCad (I usually use 123D) so decided to make my own version! I ended up with 4 variations by combining the Imperial, Interdictor and Super Star Destroyer models.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1-0.2

Infill:

10-20%
Just glue the halves together with super/CA glue once printed.

I sourced the Star Destroyers (this time using the Imperial II version which has a simpler bridge antenna) from dantesgift, and what looked like the original Death Star from kystopz89. Both of the smaller Star Destroyers got some tweaks to simplify or adjust geometry that would be difficult to print at the intended scale, then they were brought together in TinkerCad.

There were a few mesh fixes to do after exporting to STL, the nasty ones handled by Microsoft's online STL repairer and the rest using Meshmixer.

I hope you like them, and all credit to the designers of the models that went into this!

title: Meissner Tetrahedron
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is the design of an object of constant width, also known as Meißner Tetrahedron, which itself is a slghtly modified Reuleaux tetrahedron.
Print three of these tetrahedron and place something flat (like a book) on top of all three and it will roll, just like on spheres. No promises, but I think you will be amazed!

The stl file has a high resolution, and is intended for scaling.

Cetus 3d

Notes:

This part is easy to print: You will not need any infill and you will need support only at the bottom.
I would advise you to smooth out the bottom with sandpaper such as to remove any signs of the support material.

print_settings.Notes:: Also, I printed it like in the picture, laying down, for more strength.

title: Cable holder for Zaribo (and possibly mk2s)

description.text:
I trying to prevent the cable breaks that happens on previous designs by Prusa MK2s and others. The others comes lose eventually and then the cable wear down behind the sip tipe, because the cable bend under the zip tie starts moving. I'm trying to make sure it will never come lose and therefor the zip tie will never wear the cable down.

Four times in 6 months, I've had cable breaks like this. 2 times on PINDA, once on thermistor and once on the hot end fan.

Mounting: The holes are 24mm cc apart, which fits the current Zaribo-carriage. It might also fit the MK2s carriage, but I have not tested it.

I used a M3x25 and a M3x40 to mount it.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

50-75%

Notes:

I only used support under the long bit and not in the holes.

Also, I printed it like in the picture, laying down, for more strength.

Universal Slim type filament spool holder which can fit inside the sealed container with a desiccant to keep it dry from the damaging moisture for best quality prints. Axle can fit 608 bearings with 8mm dia. shaft or included bushing with a 16mm dia. tube.

This container is available here but any type of similar container will work.
https://www.amazon.co.jp/gp/product/B00774ESEG/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o01_s00?ie=UTF8&language=en_US&psc=1

Note:
Spool rotates too smoothly if using a bearing, so be sure to add a plastic zip tie, etc on the side-wall to give it a little friction to avoid it from over-rotating and filament tangling.

I made this bracelet for my step mom and named it after her. I have been beveling the edges slightly where the raceways meet at the glue joint to good effect.hand sanding the inner ring where it will contact the wearers arm and painting it with acetone will smooth it for hours of comfortable wear.  Carefully glue with acetone the inside race together. very light and check for penetration. any globs will be a bump for the airsoft balls to get past. trim along the raceway and assemble. put the inner race inside the one of the outers and load it with 6mm Airsoft balls.snap the other half down - evey one I have made held together by itself at this point. if it spins freely enough glue it carefully

An accessory for the Adafruit's Prototyping Pi Plate http://www.adafruit.com/products/801 for the Raspberry Pi. The OpenSCAD parameters can adjusted to fit difference thickness of PCBs, if you want to use it on another board. These are plastic clips that can be used to add additional support, so when you push wires into the board, it does not bend and damage the Pi connection pins. Designed to be cut out of acryllic using a laser cutter. More: http://todayimade.co/items/joe-walnes-made-laser-cut-raspberry-pi-clips

Cut these out with a laser cutter. I would recommend acrylic plastic between 3mm and 6mm thick.
Use the .dxf file if you just want to use it unmodified. If you want to make dimensional changes, or make more/less, use the .scad file and OpenSCAD.
Note: The slots are slightly different sizes (the Adafruit PCB is slightly thicker than the Pi PCB), so you may need to flip it around if it doesn't fit the first time.

title: Martian II RunCam Eagle 2 + Pro Mount

description.text:
Martian II Side Plates for the RunCam Eagle 2 and Eagle 2 Pro. Camera has 0-45deg. Assembly requires qty 6 2mm x 4mm screws, the camera should come with 4 screws that will work directly. I found some 2mm x 6mm screws from previous RunCam Cameras so I included a washer to use with the longer screws. I also designed in a spot for a 9mm OD buzzer. If the buzzer is not desired, print the non buzzer version twice, make sure that the part is mirrored in the slicing software to ensure there is a left and right version. same thing goes for if you would like the buzzer on the other side, simply use the mirror feature in the slicing software.

I have only tested with the default camera lens at 22.5deg mounting, the tips of the props are just visible but the standoffs are not. I have had a few crashes and so far the camera seems well protected still. I will be testing the RC25G lens in the future and will update the design if the camera position needs to be moved.

Buzzer I designed the part for is here, Any 9x5.5mm buzzer should work.
https://www.amazon.com/BETAFPV-Terminals-Electronic-Continuous-12X9-5mm/dp/B073RH8TQK/ref=sr_1_7?ie=UTF8&qid=1503421661&sr=8-7&keywords=drone+buzzer

I would recommend to have several prosesses so you can change the infill after need.

comments.text:
Sure you did it correctly? I did a recheck, Took a new photo and made a lithophane on the website with max width 150mm.
Downloaded the current thingiverse files and put them in S3D. They align perfectly, both at 100% scale. Ive printed 10 of them from different pictures without any problems. So has others it seems :)
comments.author: gigahertz77

comments.text: I just confirmed... size is 105, not 150... your sample image is 105 wide by 150 TALL... setting a max width of 150 in http://3dp.rocks/lithophane/ with a square or landscape image will result in a print that is too large for this holder. For anyone else using this to print: set your litho's width to 105mm; if your print is less than 150 tall then you will need to scale the z axis of this holder down, otherwise it will be tall and will stick up behind your litho.
comments.author: svennand

comments.text: Yeah you are correct. The website specify max size independent of height or width ratio. So my 150max works. But only if the picture is in standard 4:3 formfactor (whats used by most digital cameras) and the picture motive is vertical. So in other words. Use a editing software and check that the proportions are 4:3 before using 150max. Alternative scale it to fit in slicer :)

description.text:
I took the file WarHawk8080 had and scaled it up and added a Receiver Hitch to it.

I printed this on its side to minimize the supports; I also added and removed supports as required. When printing this, look over it slice-by-slice to ensure printing doesn't start without support under it.

Printer:

Creality CR-10

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.18mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Make sure all parts that start to print in the air have sufficient supports under them. As you can see from the pictures (#4 & 5), I had a piece pop off when I wasn't watching and mess up a layer (or two). I found the piece and secured it back on the support (with the help of a clean soldering iron), but it left a hole in my print.

Though I printed this at 0.18mm, 0.2mm would be fine; I will be printing this at 0.2mm from now on. Also, I don't like the support scars; so, I think I may go back to printing it with the face up. The only issue I have is that it makes the slices/layers dissect the hole used to secure it in the receiver, and I worry about separation...?

This is designed to prevent the hot end dropping after a print finishes and the steppers power off and is an alternative to over tightening the eccentric nuts and belts to prevent the power off drop.

Jan 2, 2018 Update: The mounting hole was changed to a slot and a printable twist lock was added in case you don't have spare t-nuts and bolts to mount these to the c-beam extrusions.

Position the brakes with the flex tip pointing down so they just make contact with the bottom of the carriages at their highest point. This can be attached using either a M4 or M5 t-nut if you have them or the included printable twist lock. You may also need to add commands to your end gcode to home the carriages to the top if they do not already.

This should work with one brake per carriage but if you have a heavier flying extruder setup and need extra holding power you can just mirror the stl in your slicer to print the brakes for the other side so each carriage is clamped from both sides.

description.text:
I am building an expanded Z axis vulcan 400 right now, and found it unfortunate that the 'front' of the printer was obstructed by one side of the Z support. There are two obstacles to rotating the top 90 degrees that this remix fixes. First the Z-rod top mounts are in the way of the x rods, and the y carriage motor mount run into the Z carriage. I made a new mount for the Z rod that attaches to the side of the 3030 so there is adequate clearance, and also remixed the Y carriage motor mount to move the stepper in 3mm so it has enough clearance. (also you can use a 500 mm rod for the bottom without issue, which is very easy to come by vs the 600 if you're doing carbon fiber like i am).

My top was completely assembled when i turned it, surprisingly easier than i thought it would be (because i haven't done wiring yet). i loosened the 3030 bolts securing the top pieces (leave the brackets attached to the vertical), and lift and rotate. Before re-attaching slip out your t-nuts if preassembly and slide in new ones on the sides of the 3030.

Designed in LibreCAD, with everything on one layer.

Note: Please click the "Watch" button in the upper right corner of your screen (if on a desktop) to get notified with this thing gets updated!

Parts Pack comes with instructions now!
If you need help building a 3Dtje, follow the instructions here!
https://www.instructables.com/id/Printable-I3-Style-Mini-3D-Printer-by-3Dtje/

UPDATED 1/18/18

  • Added my Cura 3.1.0 Profile for 120-150mms speeds LOL
  • Prints quite well in my opinion, so long as your printer is tuned. Let me know how it goes!

1/13/18

  • Adding "extruder spacer" which is a spring spacer and guide for the extruder. I did not have enough tension in my extruder and filament kept slipping. I designed this little thing to work in conjunction with the stock extruder housing spring slot. That way if you get good enough spring tension as is, you won't need to use this! But it's always an option!
  • Edit 1/14: This actually probably isn't needed. Turns out that my extruder was warping (made out of PLA) due to my stepper motor heating up way too much. This is why I thought I needed to put extra pressure on the filament. Turns out that most people may never need this. Keeping it in the parts pack just in case someone can use it.

1/11/18

  • Added Start-Stop G-Code for whatever slicer you use! Read the notes below before using
  • Updated Marlin configuration files. 1.1.7, and now a bit more universal. I'd use this as a template rather than just blindly using it, unless you followed my instructable to a tee.
  • Added a part cooling fan! I didn't design it, but I referenced it and added it to the pack. I REALLY like design, and how I don't need to add/wire anything, AND it actually works well!

These are some parts that helped me with building this machine. I couldn't wait for my parts to arrive from China, so I designed a few of them so I could mock things up a bit (or run extremely imprecise)

I will be adding parts to this as I design them. More details to come in my upcoming instructable!

Printable 6mm Rods:

  • Print in vase mode, they come out pretty good! Hopefully your printer is pretty solid and you don't print too fast though.
  • I put a fat skirt on this and printed it vertically. Worked pretty good.
  • Rods have an OD of 5.5mm to account for clearance issues in printed parts.
  • You may want to increase the X axis rods to around 180mm... I forgot to include that...

Y axis "shrunk" tensioner:

  • The stock one didn't fit in my Y axis unit... I shaved off a few submm from the edges and i got it to fit!

LM6UU bearing:

  • If you have actual rods, you should probably use the original files
  • If you use the printed rods, use either the 6.5mm ID or 6.3mm ID ones or even the 6.0mm ones! Try and see which ones will fit!

Y Cap:

  • If you're using undersized rods or something in the Y axis. These caps will keep your rod from slipping out as the bed moves.

10mm Feeder:

  • Since we're screwing something that has a lot of force on it sometimes (well, mine did at least), I redid the output hole to be 10mm instead of 6?mm. You may need to re-tap it with a 10mm tap however.

Z-top 3/16ths:

  • Self-explanatory. Use this if you want to use 3/16" guide rods for whatever reason

"Bowden Mount"

  • This is just a smaller bracket that can clamp down your hotend while still being able to use the included 30mm fan. The most important part of this is that it actually fits on the X c carriage with the screw holes lined up. Stock one did not for me... This does not have endstop provisions, and the holes are a little big... and long... file needs work.
  • 1/10/18 NEW DESIGN POSTED HERE: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2752997

3/16ths to 6mm adapter:

  • I didn't want to reprint my Z motor mounts, so I created this self centering adapter for my 3/16ths rods instead. This will allow for a usable-grade stiff Z axis.

Marlin Configuration files: (Updated 1/11/18)

  • These are for version 1.1.7
  • Modify them as needed
  • To use, just copy them into the Marlin directory for 1.1.7, then hit compile and upload! you will probably need to adjust the steps per MM depending on your extruder and stepper drivers.

Start-Stop G-Code: (Updated 1/11/18)

  • You'll need this if you want to print with any amount of success
  • Current omits Home axis command as I level and position my head manually
  • Add it to your favorite slicer!

Part Cooling Fan: ("Fan Cooler" and "Fan add on")

  • I really like the 2 designs I've tagged as remix sources
  • They make use of 30mm hot end fan to cool your parts!
  • Necessary if you want to print PLA with any sort of quality!
  • I have not actually remixed any of these parts, just included them in the parts pack as I feel it's necessary!

Extruder Spacer: (Added 1/13/18)

  • This part is a spring spacer and guide for the stock extruder.
  • I did not have enough tension in my extruder and filament kept slipping.
  • I designed this little thing to work in conjunction with the stock extruder housing spring slot.
  • That way if you get good enough spring tension as is, you won't need to use this! But it's always an option!

This is a collection of basic elements for 1515 extrusion work.

I have an excess amount of M3x8 screws so my brackets are configured to use them unless there's a good reason to use something else.

  • standoff - motherboard or other board (pci raiser) standoff. The feet hold the nut in place so that you don't have to align three holes at once... This is one example where M3x10 or even M3x12 is more appropriate!

  • support - off-extrusion motherboard support. Useful when extrusion is not aligned exactly with the holes that need it.

  • l-bracket-1x1 - can be used for medium-duty loads like motherboard, etc

  • l-bracket-2x2 - I use these at the corners of enclosures

  • foot - special version of l-bracket-2x2 with recesses for screw heads. Give some love to your table :)

The city of Blanos is a Persian-inspired city on the coast of a great desert in a 5th edition D&D game.

These parts can be used to make several varieties of fountains with options for the spout type and a plate that can be customized with your own spout of decorative element. The basin can be left off to make this a wall decoration instead of a fountain.

The lion head comes from the Sketchup 3D Warehouse (https://3dwarehouse.sketchup.com/model/u001baf09-4610-4753-be81-80e7451d605f/Lion-Head-Statue).

I really like TheRuttmeister's unbranded version of CosmoWenman's Venus but still wanted a base, so I combined it with a modified rock by mrbug.
I love printing figures using silver ABS (it tends to come out really rough and rocky-looking for me), so I wanted my version to look like it was emerging from stone.
At 200mm, this is the tallest single object my MakerBot Cupcake has printed so far!

• Download venus_emerges_final_bin.stl

  • Make sure that your 3D printer can reach 200mm. (I use Zydac's Z-axis extender.)

  • Be prepared for a long print. (It took 6 hours 20 mins here.)

  • Oh, and the segment between the elbow and the hip is meant to be removed afterwards. Looks good either way, though.
    • Optional: You might consider combining the separate parts yourself. There was some weirdness with my final version where the feet inside the rock became hollow areas after slicing. Printed fine, but odd. (OpenSCAD choked on the figure so I had to use Meshmixer for the union.)

comments.text: any luck getting these meshes to combine? I have had the same issue combining meshes in blender, i use boolean join op but when printed, the joined pieces create a hollow difference within each other. Have you found a way to fix this? thanks for the upload!

As part of printing a complete set of lego in 3X scale, I needed to print the wheels (https://rebrickable.com/parts/55982/, diameter 17.5mm) but didn't want to print the rubber tires. Suddenly it hit me: I have a 3X tires already, for my 42054 CLAAS XERION 5000 Tractor (https://rebrickable.com/parts/23798/, inner diameter 56mm). description.text:
This is a webcam mount for a XYZPrinting Da Vinci Duo 2.0a (though it may well fit other Da Vinci printers). It's designed for a webcam that uses a standard 1/4" tripod mount, and has been designed specifically for the Logitech C615 webcam (which works with both AstroBox and Octopi). Other cameras that are narrow and use a tripod mount likely will work as well. It has sufficient clearance to not get in the way of the print head, yet gives a good view of the action.

This mounts to the frame of the Da Vinci, rather than on the print bed itself. Since the Da Vinci moves the hot end in both X and Y, there is no need to place this on the bed to get nice time-lapse movies. The Da Vinci seems a bit picky about print bed calibration so I decided to not risk having the extra weight hanging off the bed.

You will need to remove the left side cover to install. This is easy to do, just place a stiff blade (like a putty knife) under the lip on the top and lift a bit. There are around four snaps that will release (all along the top) and the side will come off. Then you can insert the mount into the holes on the inside and simply snap the side cover back on.

description.text:
This handle is an application of the technique developed for the creation of ergonomic handles designed for the disabled people.
An example is available here : https://www.myminifactory.com/object/remake-adapted-joystick-handle-24935

The Xiaomi gimbal is designed to be installed, among other things, on a standard camera stick. With the use, this one proved to be uncomfortable, that's why, with the help of modelling paste, I developed an ergonomic handle. It was scanned with an Einscan-S, then smoothed under Meshmixer. A hole is provided for the installation of the fixing screw which comes from the excellent project found on Thingiverse : https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:899823

title: Motor Boat RC - spiral vase printable

description.text:
I wanted to make a bigger boat so I just scaled up my boat http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:204303 to 200% and edit the bow.
It can be printed in two parts each 162 mm high.
Additional it has now a propeller drive and rudder control.
It is designed to use my Roxxy BL-Outrunner which I already used for my plane http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:86982
But this Motor is so powerfull that it would drive the boat to fast without controlling the speed. Currently I am waiting for a receiver to see if I can slow it down enough.
Meanwhile I found a little dc motor diameter 24 mm and added a mount to fasten it. Even though its less power it runs well enough and it should not go much faster without risk of capsizing.
The driving shaft is a 3 mm rod and the stern tube is 4/3 mm brass tubing.
For testing it I just bonded the two parts with tape ;-)
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nzSYyld0tps&list=UUUS-GdzZ06rh8MPHkMcz0Jg Be aware that you will use it at your own risk!
Better choose flat water without waves and where you can go in - in worst case... ;-)

Printing
The best is, if you print it with spiral vase methode. Then you will get a neat surface without any noses from layer change.
The hull is 3.0 mm thick.
I printed with layer hight: 0.3 mm and width: 0.6 mm.
Anyway, you have to print it hollow with one perimeter otherwise it will not fit inside the interface part to connect the bow to the aft.
I added a small base on aft to get more brim. I printed without heatbed and used 6 mm brim. Printing the Aft
The stern is 1.2 mm thick. That means you must take four 0.3 mm solid layers on bottom to get a complete solid stern.
The top (the connection to the bow) shall not have solid layers to stay hollow.
Slice3r don't add solid layers on top, how many ever you enter. But I don't know how other slicers work. Printing the bow
Here you shall not have solid layers, just a little brim.
And yes, be very careful, if you reach the nose.
Reduce the temperature and speed by and by in small steps. Interface
The interface are supposed to put it fifty-fifty in the gap of each hull part. In this way the the hull parts are aligned and easy to glue.
Before gluing you should mask the edges of the hulls with tape to keep them clean from glue. Drive
It was designed for the Roxxy BL-Outrunner http://www.robbe.de/roxxy-bl-outrunner-2834-08.html but it is more likely that it will be to strong.
Currently I used a dc motor that tolerates even a 4 cells battery.
It has a diameter of 24 mm and a shaft of 2 mm.
Driving shaft:
3 mm rod 130 mm long with 11 mm M3 thread on one end.
Coupling:
2 heat shrink tubes
One small one und a bigger one to put them one into each other, both about 45 mm long.
I fastened the smaller one with rubber band to the motor shaft before shrinking the bigger one upon it. It is not necessary on the other side because of the longer contact surface.

comments.text:
Ich nehme an, Du meinst die Löcher für die Motorkonsole.
Im Spiralvase Modus kann man keine Löcher drucken. Dann werden vom Slicer Leerfahrten generiert, die die Rumpfhülle stören.
Soll der Rumpf dicht werden, muss der Druck kontinuierlich, ohne abzusetzen, durchlaufen. In der Druckvorschau darf keine Leerfahrt zu sehen sein. Meist fehlt dann ein Layer und der Rumpf ist undicht.
Mit dem Lötkolben Löcher rauszuschmelzen muss man erst einmal üben. Am besten ist, Du slicest nur den Bereich der Konsole und probierst es daran aus.
Ich habe ein Bild hinzugefügt, auf dem man sehen kann, wie man den Lötkolben biegt und anspitzt.

When you buy one of these false drawer storage sets, they come with two sets of hinges in the case you might have two smaller false drawers under your sink, as opposed to one large one. My case is the latter, and I wanted to make use of both sets of hinges... unfortunately they only give you one set of storage trays. This is a solution to that problem.

I had to print these in halves and glue them together as my printer build platform (and I'd assume yours) was not large enough to print the tray in one piece.

The part is designed to be parametric. You can also turn joiner tabs on or off, as well as the sponge drying tray section. Push the left and right parts together if you want a smaller tray that is not split into two halves.

This is the version im first going to try printing with, made to print laying on either side. will be printed with no support as I have added "support" to the main area that would be a problem without any... with doing so the block will need to be cut then shaved to achieve the desired finish.

I found that QuanTom's "Futuristic Christmas Tree" was a very interesting tealight LED candle cover for these festive days.
I wanted to change its size (easy to do) and shape (not so easy), so I redesigned it with OpenSCAD...
There are two boolean switches in the source file :

HIDECANDLE: Shows or hides the candle in the preview window so that you can check that your tree design will not interfere with the tealight led candle.

COVERBASE: If set, a 'sleeve' will be generated over the candle base (as you can see in the pictures)

Then, there are some variables you can change:

TreeIdx: Set this from 1 to n, n being the last tree description in the "Trees" descriptor vector. I provide here 6 different trees. The first two ones are larger and are more like the original one designed by QuanTom.

Trees: This is the trees description vector. See the source file comments to understand the values.

Take care to check the "CandleBD" value and to adjust it to the external diameter of your LED candles. Usually the external shell of these candles is slightly conical. If you use a value between the smaller and the larger candle diameter, then the generated 'sleeve' wil lock itself over the candle base and the candle will not 'fall' into the printed tree if you push it (slighty).

Merry Christmas to everyone...

title: Phone Adapter For a Camera Tripod

description.text:
I needed a to use my wife's phone on a camera tripod, so I made this adapter to attach a cheap vent clip phone holder to a camera tripod. My wife thought it worked great, and she even decided to use the phone mounted so that the screen was against the bar of the adapter so she could cover the screen and reduce the light while filming in a theater.

You will need a nut that matches the thread of your tripod or camera mount. The Hexagon at the bottom is 10 mm from flat side to flat side, so resize it as needed.

Printer:

ORDBot Hadron

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

.2 mm vertical layers

Infill:

I used 70% but you could go as low as 40%

I used a 1/4" Nut with coarse thread (20 Threads per inch) to match the thread on my tripod. You may need to use a different thread or different sized nut, so be prepared to resize the hexagonal hole.

To set the nut into the plastic, I heated the nut with a heat gun and pressed the adapter down onto the nut, melting the plastic around it. That was why I used the higher fill density. The nut is now fused in place.
This was designed using Cubify Invent, but it could have been done just as easily in Fusion 360 or TinkerCAD.

title: D-bot hot-end Cable Chain
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The weight of the wiring going to the hot-end on my D-Bot derived printer was high enough that none of the normal ways of supporting them (3mm filament, PTFE tubing, etc) would support them well enough to not sag, occasionally getting in the way of the X gantry.

A rigid cable chain was a better solution, however the existing ones used with the D-bot were both too small for the number of wires necessary for a dual-extruder hot-end with a BLTouch, but they required feeding all the wires through the chain at installation time, making a huge job if they never need to be replaced.

This design is wider -- more than twice as much area within the chain -- and has a clip-based design that keeps the outer side of the chain completely open until the clips are added. The clips fit in snuggly and securely hold even a fairly substantial bundle of wires.

The hot-end clip replaces the PTFE support, and screws into the stock bolt holes. The fixed end is designed to mount on the rear of the printer (which is where I had my wires running).

Installing is pretty simple. Just replace the PTFE support on the hot-end with the hot-end clip, screw the other end into the rear 4020 rail, and clip together enough of the individual links to match the length of the wires. I'm using 29 for a 300x300 bed. Run the wires in a bundle within the chain, and lock them in place with the front clip. Pay attention to the direction you clip it -- there's teeth that hook around the inside of the link to keep it in place so it won't slide out. Note that the rear end has the link attachment reversed. That's normal.

Printer:

DBot

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.15 or .2mm

Infill:

50%

Notes:

I printed the links and clip at .15mm, with sufficient perimeters to have them solid (no infill). The brackets were both printed .2mm, with 50% infill. They'd probably be fine less, but that's the "standard" I printed all the parts on the printer.

The brackets will both need supports unless you have some sort of magic printer or are in free-fall on the space station or something.

description.text:
Remixed from Talismancer's simple-yet-brilliant coin model, I created a 1st player token for the Arctic Scavengers board game as a more thematic replacement to the initiator card that comes with it.

I'm really only comfortable with Sketchup at this very early stage in my 3D modelling habit, so the coin sides were made from scratch using measurements from the original.

Thank you so much for your design Talismancer, I am continually amazed by how simple and elegant a solution this is.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

25%

Much as with the original design, you'll want to add a washer in-between the two coin sides to give it some weight (it lends the token that much more gravitas). I used an M10 2mm x 22.5mm washer for this purpose, though a slightly larger in diameter washer would have been nicer.

After that, simply glue the pieces together using whatever filament appropriate glue you have. Feel free to go roughly on the glue, as when painted over this only lends to the uneven and aged look you would expect coins minted in a post-apocalyptic snow-barren wasteland to have.

  • Cut at them lightly to give them an aged look; I also roughly shaved the sides in random patterns to make them less even.
  • Prime them black.
  • Dry brush them dark silver.
  • Wash them with a very thin black paint.
  • Finally seal them with a matte spray paint sealer.

The images used for each coin side - the balaclava, and the knife with hammer - are the symbols used to represent "mercenaries" and "tools" from the game respectively. These were taken directly from the rulebook pdf, then traced onto each coin side and raised.

comments.text: Mine is fine, no warping or weakness in the material. I have about 100 hours of printing time with the fan shroud. Since I only print in PLA at 196-197C, my heat sink doesn't get hot as long as the fan is blowing air on it. Maybe someone else can comment about 240-250C temperature ranges for printing ABS, but I think it should be fine. Heat sink temperatures shouldn't even come close to material melting point.

print_settings.Notes:: Pi Mount: 25%

title: Raspberry Pi Zero W and Camera Mount for 2020 and heated bed (AM8/Others)

description.text:
WIP: Raspberry Pi Zero W and CSI Camera v1.3 heated bed mount for AM8 and other variants.

The design is now printable and tested and is use on my own printer, it can be considered a completed design until further additions are made.

26 Dec 17 - Octopi installed, images updated guides updated.
25 Dec 17 - It was christmas, too full and drunk for thingiverse!
24 Dec 17 - Wiring made, mounted and powers on.
22 Dec 17 - Pi Mount test print, adjustment of dimensions, adjusted design, re-uploaded.
21 Dec 17 - Added Pi Mount Design, not printed yet.
19 Dec 17 (2) - Second print along with test fit, adjustment to dimensions, re-uploaded, guide added.
19 Dec 17 - First print, adjustment to dimensions, re-uploaded, images added.
18 Dec 17 - Initial Upload.

Still to do:
Fit LED to X carriage
Fit relays to Mainboard+Mosfet power.

Camera mount requires:
1x M3X30mm
1x M3X20mm
2x M3 nut
30cm Raspberry Pi Zero CSI Camera Cable http://amzn.to/2DgUukJ
Raspberry Pi Camera http://amzn.to/2DSyhKF

Pi mount requires:
4x M3X30mm
4xM3 nut
2xM5x8mm
2xM5 T-Nut
12v to 5v Converter http://amzn.to/2kB4xdd
Raspberry Pi Zero http://amzn.to/2pDZxtg

Wiring requires:
Heat shrink
5.3mm blue fork connector http://amzn.to/2zwX4Rj
Soldering iron and solder
Right angle Micro USB cable http://amzn.to/2zyfJMo
Right angle USB B cable http://amzn.to/2DfJfZT

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.24

Infill:

25%

Notes:

Printed in PETG
Camera mount: 25%
Camera swivel: 50%+
Camera plate: 50%+

Pi Mount: 25%

Camera mount assembly:

Firstly, attach the camera swivel to the heated bed mount using the M3X20mm bolt, through both parts, into the nut captured inside the heated bed mount.

Secondly, attach the camera plate to the camera swivel, using the M3X30mm bolt, into the m3 nut captured on the other side. The fit for the nut is tight, if you have difficulty making it fit, try heating the nut with a lighter then inserting it.

Thirdly, attach the ribbon cable to the camera, insert through the slot in the camera plate and press fit the camera onto the posts.

Lastly, remove the heated bed and attach the mount to the "H" Bed using the pre existing 4mm bolts.

Pi mount assembly:

Insert 4x 3mm nuts into the base of pi mount, use a lighter to heat the nuts to make fitment easy and tight.

Insert 2xM5x8mm through the remaining holes on the mount and loosely threat the M5 T-Nuts onto it.

Insert 4x M3X30mm Nuts through the raspberry pi, this will be a tight fit.
Insert the spacers onto the nuts, with the cut outs facing inwards and away from the Pi.

Clip the 12v to 5v converter to the Pi mount.

You can now place the Pi and spacers, over the converter and into the mount.

Wiring:

This is mostly optional, the same can be achieved using adaptors and wall plugs, although I wanted an integrated and semi-permanent solution.

Cut and splice USB B and USB Micro cables and solder 4 internal wires together, ensuring they're insulated from each other.

Solder the 5v 3a positive (red) to GPIO pin 4 on the Raspberry Pi and the negative (black) to GPIO pin 6.

Extend the yellow wire (positive) and use a fork terminal to attach to a spare 12v positive slot on the PSU, extend the black wire and again with a fork terminal attach to a 12v negative slot on the PSU.

Insert the camera cable into the ribbon slot.

Here's a guide to install OctoPi

title: 3D LabPrint Stearman PT-17 motor mount adapter

description.text:
This allows you to use an ordinary motor without having to reverse the shaft on 3D LabPrint's PT-17.

The original design cracked on me the first time flying and I wasn't too thrilled about reprinting that piece or trying to fix it. I prefer not reversing my motors either as I often grave rob parts and all my other planes use non-reversed motors.

To use this you're either going to have to carve out the nose as I did or if you have yet to print the part, I would recommend importing the STL to your CAD program and do a boolean subtract with a cylinder to remove that area from the start. That saves you a lot of wasted filament in support material. I would do so and upload the modifed part, but I'm not sure if that would go against their license.

I recommend printing in PETG or at least something stronger than PLA.

You're going to need 16mm m3 bolts

Retighten the bolts after the first flight. Mine loosened up.

print_settings.Notes:: And I printed them at 0,10 mm resolution

description.text:
I tried a lot of models found on the web and never got a really functional printable playmobil

I decided to make my own, here it is

I had to change some parts to print them in separate sub parts to make them strong and reliable.

Skeleton has a separate part really easy to plug in the main part
the Head is also in two parts I had to separate the neck to print it horizontally it's much stronger like that.
It's best to print the neck with another part because of the tiny last layers if there is some cooling time between layers the part is much cleaner.

At the end I separated also the shoes from the legs in order to print with another color.

hair is also two parts to avoid supports, You can find one with supports but the result is much better with the two parts one, they clip together.

Pay attention to the hands I printed them with a really dense support with Simplify3D at 0,1 mm layer height all the other parts don't need support and are printed at 0,2 mm

to get them fit in the arms you need to remove little spikes on the wrist, if it is too hard to get the hand fit in the arm you will break it (I broke one).

Also when assembling shoes and legs it's a bit hard to get it inside but the connection is strong and the shoes won't fall after a few movements, don't try to get the shoes off you will break them (broke one also).

I left the whole one with legs and shoes if you want the same color

That's it I hope some people will try to print this

Last note, all parts can be used with real Playmobil parts they fit together

author: ScottyMakesStuff

description.text:
Just turned the rather excellent Makerbot igloo into an ornament to hang wherever you please :)

There's now a v2 with a beefed up hoop, the other one might be a little flimsy depending on settings/materials.

Just a little wheel for manual filament advance. Press fits on a NEMA 17 shaft (15mm with a 0.5mm flat with no screwin' around. I highly suggest pausing and changing filament for the top layers just to make the pentacle pop.

Blessed Be~.

I've been holding off uploading this for a long time on uploading this. I feel at this point that it's durable enough where I feel comfortable with other people trying to use it. I just don't want other people to have a bad experience on something I made. Just know this isn't perfect by any means.

So if you're building this, everything lines up pretty much in line with the storch plans. The parts that glue onto the fuselage use the line where you would otherwise glue the wire in as front most part of cut you need to make for it to fit. For the wire, the bends are at the same spots, just at different angles. You want about 30mm before the bend for the ends that fit into the plastic parts on the fuselage. For the tail wheel, I dimensioned that part, based off of my storch build from plans where I cut off the end of the bottom fuselage piece where those two thin slivers of foam would otherwise be. It's going to seem too small if build from kit, but it can be made to work by cutting slits in the foam. The part called "gear guide" is the only thing I've managed to break so far. I would recommend printing that part out of PETG or at least something stronger than PLA. Keep a few spares on hand.

I did include the FreeCAD files if anyone wants to make any changes. Good luck to you, they are a total mess.

22 Dec 17 edit: So I've been flying this plane a lot more recently. I still have yet to break anything but the guide clip on my plane. I made one of these for a friend learning to fly and he's managed to bust both bottom fuselage pieces, but these were crashes that probably would have torn the gear out of the fuselage if glued. For the guide piece, I upscaled the part to 105% and it seems that with the rod clipped in, the area where it usually breaks is under a lot less stress. I think I'm going to be breaking these less often with this change. After I get some time to test it out, if it works better, I'll update that file.

title: Tevo Little Monster Delta - Detailed Build Walkthrough

description.text:
I'm new to 3d printing and apparently picked a hard printer to start with.

My difficulty is YOUR gain!

I've documented my build process, some recommended changes in the build order, how to download and flash all the firmware, and how I used software to manually run the calibration (to avoid the dreaded plate smashing). I hope this helps folks, let me know and I'll add more details for anywhere I've forgotten.

One quick note: You may want to get some tools (while your printer is in the mail) to make your build faster and easier, see the tools section below

READ ME: More tips and hints from the Tevo forum (https://tevo-3d-printers.com/viewtopic.php?f=27&t=305)
READ ME: Recommended upgrades from the Tevo forum (https://tevo-3d-printers.com/viewtopic.php?f=27&t=351)

Also note: A walkthrough of software and manual control of the printer is still in progress... the current version is available at: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2722557

last note: The browser crashed a couple times while I was writing this. I don't think I lost anything, but post or email if something seems off and I'll get it fixed.

Updates:

  • I will add change history as updates are made
  • 12/29/17: Added links to Tevo Forum with tips and upgrades
  • 12/20/17: Added Config File
  • 12/20/17: Initial Add

I recently received my Tevo Little Monster Delta printer. It arrived in about a week. I immediately noticed that it is enormous! The other thing I quickly found is that folks online have had a fair amount of difficulty getting everything to work. I am attempting to capture all of my notes and successes below to help everyone else. When my Tivo Little Monster Delta (TLMD) arrived, I opened the box to find two layers of foam packaged parts and a plastic bag with instructions, a pack list, a business card with links to facebook and a small red 2 page booklet with support instructions. Do This First
Validate all parts against packing list I solidly recommend you inventory all parts and ensure you have everything. The packing list is a single page. It contains a listing of items on the A layer (38 items A-1 through A-19), items on the B layer (8 items B-1 through B-3) and a diagram showing where all the items are on each layer. I easily found everything except for item A-17, the "Slot Cover." It was, of course, in the package, but I could not find it. The Slot Cover is a small plastic trim piece that inserts into the side of the 4080 extrusion to contain the wires (later in the build) powering the heated bed and thermistor(?) that go from the controller to the heated bed. The Slot Covers (2) were of course already seated in the extrusion and low profile enough that I simply did not notice them, nor know what they were, to look for them.

Preparation: Tools You Actually Need Get your tools Having confirmed that you have all your parts, assemble your tools! I found the following to be very useful in my build. I have also identified things that WOULD have been useful if I'd realized in advance. Note: find the included tools. The packing list does not make it clear that these are included in the A-9-2 bag. Useful Tools:
  • A small bowl or tub to hold screws
  • Electric Screwdriver / Drill with torque control
  • Metric Hex Bits (#5 - 4mm, #3 - 2.5mm and #2.5 - 2mm)
  • Thin Metric Hex Screwdrivers of the same sizes (to get into tight spaces)
  • Small Wrench (included) for adjusting the eccentric nuts
  • A 3/16 socket (or adjustable wrench) to put in brass standoffs
  • Small Clippers to cut all the small zip ties and the PTFE tube
  • a small wood toothpick to remove paper from the plexiglass
  • A Computer with an SD Card reader
  • A new Fullsize SD Card for the touch display (recommended)
  • A new Micro SD Card for the main board (recommended)
  • A Micro SD to regular SD Adaptor
  • I'll add more as I think of it

Make the Basic Frame

The printed instructions appear to have gone through multiple revisions without a clear way to reference each. The below link is to an older version than mine (but is similar). I've added part info, suggested changes, some order changes and notes.

https://s3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/3dprintersbay/Tevo-Little-Monster/TEVO+little+Monster+Manual.pdf

Page 2: ASSEMBLY BAG B-3-1
My instruction booklet differs (see first image). As of at least December 2017, the heated bed, heated bed mounting plate and base plate are shipped attached to each other. Remove the screws and separate the baseplate, heated bed and surface sticker. Put the screws somewhere safe as you will need them in about 10 steps.

Note: Make sure the feet are on the bottom of the base plate, which has recessed holes for the heads of the screws in the next step.

You will need:

  • B-1: Bottom Plate
  • Bag B-3-1: containing 6 rubber feet and 6 screws

Page 2: BAG A-2-2
Attach the extrusions to the bed. In videos online, people have hung the baseplate off of a table, or stood it up on all the legs. I attached the first leg, then stood up the base on all three legs, attached two screws in each for stability, then screwed in the remaining screws.

Note: Consider removing the two A-17 Slot Covers and putting them to the side. later you can attach them to whichever extrusion is at the rear of your machine.

You will need:

  • A-2: Bag A-2-2
  • A-17: 4080 Extrusion
  • A-18: 4080 Extrusion
  • A-19: 4080 Extrusion

RECOMMENDED OUT OF ORDER STEP
I recommend you jump ahead and ensure all endstop activation screws are the same length now. This is much harder to do later.

I did the following. I took two carriages and faced the tops toward each other. I then had the screw of one rest on the top of the second, and adjusted each until they were the same size. I repeated with all three.

Page 3: BAG A-10
Attach the Vertical Carriages. These now come pre-assembled. You may still need to adjust the spacing between the bearings. This is done by rotating the eccentric nuts with the included wrench (in Bag A-9-2).

How wide should these be? The Carriages should not wiggle, nor should they be to tight. If someone has good guidance on appropriate fit, please post a comment and I'll update this section.

Make sure the drive belt extends both above and below the carriage. Make sure all the Carriages are inserted the same way with the attached mounting point at the top.

You will need:

  • A-10 Vertical Carriage
  • A-11 Vertical Carriage
  • A-12 Vertical Carriage

RECOMMENDED OUT OF ORDER STEP
I recommend you jump ahead and install the brass standoffs for the optical sensors.

If you wait until later, it is extremely hard to get your hands in the right place to screw them in, and many things are attached to the top plate discouraging flipping the printer to simplify install

Page 8: BAG A-9-1
Attach the brass standoffs for the optical end stops. There are six of these. Put the remaining parts back in the back for a later step.

The standoffs go in the bottom of the top end plate next to the two square cut out holes. Note: they should be on the opposite side from the recessed screw holes. Optional: you can loosely install the optical end stops, however they will need to be able to wiggle and adjust out of the way when you install the top onto the extrusions.

You will need:

  • A-9-1: 6 Brass standoffs
  • optional: A-9-1: 3 optical end stops
  • optional: A-9-1: 6 hex screws to attach optical end stops

Page 4: BAG A-2-2
Install the top end plate. Note: make sure the "notch" faces whatever side you want to be the back. Pay attention to this notch as several things must align to it. If you have already installed the brass standoffs and/or optical sensors, be careful when putting on the top as they may bump into the feet.

You will need:

  • A-2-2: Containing screws to attach the top plate

Page 5 & 6: BAG A-8
Install the Stepper Motor Mounts, Stepper Motors, Pulleys and Belts. There is a lot of play in the mounts. You may want to mount them closer to the edge of the Top end plate to allow more space to run wires later.

Note: This page identifies which motors are X, Y and Z, needed later to wire up the cables. This is not called out ANYWHERE else. (I'll mention again in the wiring stage).

Note: The belt pulleys have two set screws. I made sure one was flat on the flat side of the stepper motor and the second ended up where ever. Tighten both well.

You will need:

  • A-8: 3 Stepper Motor Mounts
  • A-8: Parts Pack
  • A-14: Stepper Motor
  • A-15: Stepper Motor
  • A-16: Stepper Motor

Page 7: BAG A-2-1
Tension the Belts

Note: Make sure the belt sits correctly in the Idler Pulley. Mine wanted to sit on the side of the idler and would have come lose later.

Note: Make sure the T-Nuts are loose enough to get behind the T extrusion versus turning and holding tight against the side. If you look down from above, you should be able to see them turn as you tighten them.

You will need:

  • A-2-1 Parts Pack: tensioner hardware

Page 8: BAG B-3-2
Install the Heated Bed

Note: Make sure the cables are aligned to the notch in the top plate signifying the rear leg.

You will need:

  • Screws from step one: separating the heated bed
  • B-3-2 Parts Pack: spacers

Page 8: BAG A-9-1

If you have not already, install and tighten the optical end stops

Page 9: BAG A-7
Install effector and print nozzle

Note: You will want to manually raise the Carriages so there is room to install the connecting rods.

Note: The effector appears to have a front. The sensor probe goes in the back, the two screws in the top ring face the front. See the second image, the front of the effector is facing up.

You will need:

  • A-7 Connecting Rods
  • A-7 Parts Pack
  • A-6 Effector

Page 9: BAG A-7
Install effector and print nozzle

Note: You will want to manually raise the Carriages so there is room to install the connecting rods.

Note: The effector appears to have a front. The sensor probe goes in the back, the two screws in the top ring face the front. In the image below, the front is facing up.

You will need:

  • A-7 Connecting Rods
  • A-7 Parts Pack
  • A-6 Effector

RECOMMENDED OUT OF ORDER STEP
I recommend you jump ahead and install the extruder and PTFE tube while you are working on this level.

Page 11: BAG A-13

Note: Once you press the tube into the clamp, it will not come out, I have not yet figured out how to release it. Please comment and I'll update this. Thanks.

Note: In efforts to get good tension on the belts, I first attached spring clips to each (over the doubled back belt) to keep them from slipping. I then moved the hot end far from one leg, found a reasonably taught distance and zip tied the belt over itself. I used two zip ties on each belt. I then repeated this for each direction and then put on the springs.

You will need:

  • A-9-1 Belt Springs
  • A-9 Zip Ties
  • A-9 PTFE Tube (aka. Bowden Tube, aka. Teflon Tube)
  • A-13 Extruder

Page 10: BAG A-1
Install the display mount and spool holder

Note: the display holder hangs under the front of the top build plate (opposite the notch). The spool holder attaches to the left rear of the center hole.

You will need:

  • A-1 Spool Holder
  • A-1 Spool Holder Rack
  • A-1 Display Holder
  • A-1 Parts Pack

RECOMMENDED OUT OF ORDER STEP
I recommend you place the touch screen and run the ribbon cable BEFORE installing the main board as the opening is under it.

Page 13: BAG A-5

The display just hangs on the hooks. Feed the cable up through the hole and I recommend out to the left (it will wrap over the main board after the main board is installed)

You will need:

  • A-5 Display

Page 12: BAG A-3
Install the electronics board (Picture 3)

Note: The main board is a "smoothie board" whose company is not apparently contributing to the smoothie effort (code, funding or other) and is looked badly on in the community. Please consider donating or otherwise supporting the un-reimbursed originators of our boards and software, smoothieware. http://smoothieware.org/

Note: Before you take out or unwrap the electronics board, install the brass standoffs first! You should also consider loosely installing the hinges onto the electronics cover box.

When I took the board out, it was mostly assembled and chock full of wires. I spent several minutes carefully unwrapping everything. I ended up re-wiring everything multiple times.

Note: Before you install the board, check the two jumpers on the main board are set to 5V and 32 respectively. They are at the end opposite the USB connector, one in each corner.

Note: Before you install the board, run the black corrugated cable holder through one of the holes in the back.

It took me several tries to get everything installed happily.

You will need:

  • A-3 Main Board
  • A-3 Parts Pack

Page 13: BAG A-4
Install the Power Supply

My PSU did not nicely align with all of the pre drilled holes and took some wiggling.

Note: Check the power setting on the back of your PSU. Mine was set to the wrong power (220 instead of 110). If this is wrong, you will blow your board.

You will need:

  • A-4 PSU Case
  • A-4 Parts Pack

Page 14
Wiring everything up

DO NOT TURN ON YOUR PRINTER UNTIL YOU HAVE UPDATED THE FIRMWARE... see below

Although this page is enhanced in the new manual, I still found this page to be severely lacking. Below I've laid out everything I did and went through to wire up my TLMD.

Heater Bed Thermistor
Run the black thermistor cable across the top of the machine to the back extruder leg. I had to run mine under the rear stepper motor next to the power supply. I ran the cable down the back of the extruder. Connect it to the matched connector in the heated bed.

Heater Bed Power
In A-9, find the white cable (two wires) with the twist lock connector. Connect it to the power supply and run it down the back leg of your printer. I ran each wire in a separate channel and then used the slot cover (see first step) to hold each in place. I'm considering cutting the slot covers into three pieces and using two for each wire and channel.

Stepper Motors
There is a wire for each stepper and optical endstop. Facing the front of the machine, X (Alpha) is the front left. Y (Beta) is the front right. Z (Gamma) is the back. Run the wires through which ever hole best fits and connect as appropriate.

Extruder and Hot End
The giant black wire bundle disappointingly does not have strain relief. I encourage you to use a zip tie to attach it to the housing case. At the bottom, there does not appear to be any way to get all the wires and connectors through the small hole in the extruder plate. I zip tied mine to the side. Connect all the wires. Pay special attention to the BLTouch wires. there are two sets. One is black and white. One is orange. yellow and brown. These must be aligned correctly

Note: Right Now, double check your BL Touch wires are correctly aligned. If they are wrong, your printer with smash the hot end into the base plate... a lot.

Power
In A-9 find the cable with a twist lock on each end. Run it from the power supply to the main board. I found that my cable keeps wanting to fall on top of a stepper motor. I may ultimately print some cable management clips of some sort.

USB
We will not use it till later, but find the USB cable in A-9 and have it handy.

Updating all of the Firmware

Do not turn on your printer until you have updated the firmware

Update the Mainboard Firmware

The MKS Base is a knock off Smoothieboard. Note: MKS has a bad rep for having leveraged all of the work of the open source community but not giving anything back (development help, funding, etc). Consider supporting Smoothieboard (http://www.smoothieboard.org).

To update your mainboard firmware you will need a Micro SD to regular SD Adaptor. I also recommend you get a new SD Card so that you can keep the original... just in case. If you use your existing card, make sure to overwrite the "firmware.bin" file.

Download the newest Smoothieboard firmware "firmware.bin" at this link:

https://github.com/Smoothieware/Smoothieware/tree/edge/FirmwareBin

Insert your Micro SD Card into the SD Card adaptor and insert it into your computer. Backup your existing micro SD card (you will need the config file). Eject and insert your new Micro SD Card. Copy the existing config file named "config" and the "firmware.bin" file onto the Micro SD card. Eject it from your computer and put it back into the printer mainboard. Make sure it is fully inserted.

Update the Touch Screen Firmware
Note: I am including the below for completeness, however I have not gotten the display to work correctly and instead control my printer via the USB (see the post linked in the summary of this post at the top).

MKS TFT Firmware can be found here. This is the latest version.

https://github.com/makerbase-mks/MKS-TFT/tree/master/MKS-TFT2.8-3.2/Firmware

I downloaded the "TFT28 32_V3.0.0_English.zip" file and unzipped it into a directory. You definitely want a new SD Card for this. The supplied SD card has already had software and data installed onto it (find the cut in the packaging). Insert this into your computer and make a backup up copy.

Download and unzip the above new firmware file. You must copy over all your old config information into the new file. I've attempted to attach the text of mine below (formatting is messy). There are three styles and two colors of images in the new firmware. I don't know how to preview it, nor which is the original.

When complete, copy the "mks_config.txt" "mks_pic" directory and "mkstft28.bin" files onto the new SD Card. Eject this from your computer and insert it back into the display.

Flash the Firmware onto the Printer
Once you have updated both SD cards and firmly inserted them, power up your printer. On the main board, you will see some green lights in the front left corner that will flash rapidly. The touch screen will display a loading message while it loads the newest firmware.

Once complete, you should be able to control your printer from the touch screen.

Note: calibrate still did not work correctly for me with the touch screen. I used manual control to successfully calibrate my printer and test the BLTouch. Instructions are linked from the summary at the top of this posting.

#--------------------------------------------------------------------
#########  Printer type setting  ##################################

#mainboard firmware setting(marlin:1; repetier:2; smoothie:3)
>cfg_firmware_type:3

#machine setting (Normal:1; Delta:2)
>cfg_machine_type:2

#baud rate (9600:1; 57600:2; 115200:3; 250000:4)
>cfg_baud_rate:3

#multi-language(enable:1, disable:0)
>cfg_multiple_language:1

#languages setting
#(simplified Chinese:1; traditional Chinese:2; English:3; Russian:4; Spanish:5). This configuration is valid when "cfg_multiple_language" is disabled.
>cfg_language_type:3

#enable auto off after print finish function (no:0; Yes:1）
>cfg_print_finish_close_Machine:0

#pause position (-1 is invalid; Z-axis is relative position)
>cfg_XPOS:-1
>cfg_YPOS:-1
>cfg_ZADD:10

#extruder number(one:1; dual:2)
>cfg_sprayer_counter:1

#enable heated bed(yes:1; no: 0)
>cfg_custom_bed_flag:1

#the max target temp of extruder and heated bed
>cfg_max_sprayer_temperature:270
>cfg_max_hotbed_temperature:150

#set PB0 signal when use it for sencond nozzle (high level:1; low level:0)
>cfg_PB0_trigger_Level:1

#set PB1 signal (high level:1; low level:0)
>cfg_PB1_trigger_Level:1

#############  WIFI Function  ##########################################

#wifi model(MKS WIFI TFT:0;  MKS HLK-WIFI:1)
>cfg_wifi_type:0

#wifi mode(AP:1; STA:2)
>cfg_wifi_mode:1

#wifi name and password
>cfg_wifi_ap_name:TEVO_Monster
>cfg_wifi_key_code:1234567890

#0:disable cloud service 1:enable cloud service
>cfg_cloud_enable:0
#cloud service adress
#>cfg_wifi_cloud_host:www.baizhongyun.cn
#cloud service port
#>cfg_cloud_port:10086

#Dynamic access IP
>cfg_ip_dhcp_flag:1

#IP/mask/gateway
>cfg_ip_address:192.168.3.100
>cfg_ip_mask:255.255.255.0
>cfg_ip_gate:192.168.3.1

#--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

#---------------------------------------------------------------------------------
##### Display Customization(button and logo customized see User's Manual) #######

#the color of screen background
>cfg_background_color:0x000000

#the color of title text
>cfg_title_color:0xFFFFFF

#the color of temperature,fan,(etc) background
>cfg_state_background_color:0x000000

#the color of temprature,fan,(etc) text
>cfg_state_text_color:0xFFFFFF

#the color of file button
>cfg_filename_background_color:0x000000

#the color of file text
>cfg_filename_color:0xFFFFFF

#the color of background in printing 
>cfg_printingstat_word_background_color:0x000000

#the color of text in printing status
>cfg_printingstat_word_color:0xFFFFFF

#3D effects setting (disable: 0; enable: 1)
>cfg_BUTTON_3D_effects:0

#屏幕翻转180°(0:不翻转,1:翻转)
>cfg_OVERTURN_180:0

#-----------------------------------------------------------------------
#########  Advanced Function Option  ##################################

#enable UPS?(yes:1; no:0)
>cfg_have_ups_device:0

#enable power detecting module(mks 220det:1; mks pwc:0)
>cfg_insert_det_module:0

#set error range of Z-axis on breakpoints recovery 
>cfg_breakpoint_z_error:0.2

#---------------------------------------------------------------------------

#########  Filament Change Function  ##############################

#the speed to extrude filament(mm/min)
>cfg_filament_load_speed:1200
#the lenght to extrude filament (mm)
>cfg_filament_load_length:200

#the speed to retract filament(mm/min)
>cfg_filament_unload_speed:1200
#the lenght to retract filament(mm)
>cfg_filament_unload_length:200

#It is the minimum temperature for filament change.
It will auto heat up if the current temp doesn't reach the target.
>cfg_filament_load_limit_temperature:200

#---------------------------------------------------------------------------

############  Leveling Function  ########################################

#leveling mode(manual:0; auto:1; conceal leveling button:2)
>cfg_leveling_mode:1

#the command of auto leveling (G29 is available for Marlin.While G32 is for  Repetier and Smoothieware)
>cfg_auto_leveling_cmd:G28;G32;

#the point number of manual leveling:(3,4,5 point available)
>cfg_point_number:4

#the coordinates of 5 point on manual leveling
>cfg_point1:50,50
>cfg_point2:180,50
>cfg_point3:180,180
>cfg_point4:50,180
>cfg_point5:150,150

#the travel speed of leveling(mm/min)
>cfg_leveling_z_speed:1500
>cfg_leveling_xy_speed:3000

#---------------------------------------------------------------------------

############## Function Customization #######################################

#user-defined function1 and 2.(display this button .  disable: 0; enable: 1)
>cfg_function_btn1_display:1
>cfg_function_btn2_display:1

#command of user-defined function
>function_btn1_cmd:M84;
>function_btn2_cmd:M280_S10.6;G28;M280_S3;M190_S80;G32;G31;M374;M500;M280_S7;G28;M140_S0;M84;reset;

#what the new config had
#>function_btn2_cmd:M81;

#set number of  "More" button 
>moreitem_pic_cnt:7

#edit command for 1~7 "More" button,each command must be separated by semicolon ";"
#what the new config had
#>moreitem_button1_cmd:G28 X0;

#>moreitem_button2_cmd:G28 X0;

#>moreitem_button3_cmd:G28 Y0;

#>moreitem_button4_cmd:G28 Y0;

#>moreitem_button5_cmd:G28 Z0;

#>moreitem_button6_cmd:G28 Z0;

#>moreitem_button7_cmd:G28;
>moreitem_button1_cmd:M280 S7;

>moreitem_button2_cmd:M280 S3;

>moreitem_button3_cmd:M280 S10.6;

>moreitem_button4_cmd:M280 S8.4;

>moreitem_button5_cmd:G28;G0 F8000 X0 Y0 Z250;M42;M109 T0 S240;G92 E0;G1 E50 F300;G1 E150 F3000;G92 E0;G1 E100 F300;M104 S0;G28;

>moreitem_button6_cmd:G28;G0 F8000 X0 Y0 Z250;M42;M109 T0 S240;G92 E0;G1 E20 F300;G1 E-350 F3000;M104 S0;G28;

>moreitem_button7_cmd:M84;

#how many "More" button display on screen interface
>morefunc_cnt:0

#command setting on button1~6
>morefunc1_cmd:G28;

>morefunc3_cmd:G28;
>morefunc4_cmd:G28;

print_settings.Notes:: I tried printing my model without a raft however, about 3/4 of the way through the print it came unstuck from my print bed. A raft is probably unnecessary but I used one to make sure my model stuck.

description.text:
I have a 2006 Mustang GT with a manual transmission and I wanted to try to make a shifter knob for it. This is designed for an aftermarket shifter (Hurst) so the size of the hole in the bottom may need to be changed if you have a stock shifter.

I do want to give credit where credit is due, I did not design the tribar pony logo it was designed and uploaded to Thingiverse by tsprenger on May 6th 2015 (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:812300). I did design the ball and edit his logo so it would fit on the ball. This is my first upload to thingiverse and I hope I am giving credit properly (added him in sources & mentioned him here).

I hope you enjoy my model
-Jake Parker

Printer:

Monoprice Select V2

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.1

Infill:

quarter cubic

Notes:

I tried printing my model without a raft however, about 3/4 of the way through the print it came unstuck from my print bed. A raft is probably unnecessary but I used one to make sure my model stuck.

print_settings.Printer:: XYZ Printing da Vinci Jr. 1.0 wireless

title: Christmas Story Leg Lamp LED remix

description.text:
I have always enjoyed the Christmas Story movie, especially the leg lamp scene. I figured someone must have designed a printable version, and sure enough a search produced 2 designs I liked.

Christmas Story leg lamp remix for LED lighting https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1978458 by cmh(Chris Heerschap) https://www.thingiverse.com/cmh/about

and Christmas Story Leg Lamp https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2648470 by jetpuf (Brian Webber) https://www.thingiverse.com/jetpuf/about

I liked jetpuf's separation of cmh's design, and decided I could try to add small battery powered LED's to the design, so here is my remix.

Thanks Chris and Brian!! Enjoy!!!

Printer:

XYZ Printing da Vinci Jr. 1.0 wireless

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

hollow

Notes:

Add brim to leg to make sure it stays attached to print table. Printed leg at 0.1mm height for better "curves" and hollow for light to shine without structure showing. Printed leg in white PLA and colored the shoe red with a Sharpie marker even though the shoe was black in the movie, I wanted it to stand out from the black base.

Print the shade low density to allow light through, I printed 5%. I used 0.3mm height. Update: I printed the larger one labeled 130 and I prefer that scale and size for this print. I've added a picture and made it the cover photo, also, I added a picture of the smaller one on top for comparison.

Printed the base at 20%, 0.3mm height, but you can print how you best see fit. The base prints standing up to allow the pins to print correctly. I printed without supports and it came out fine.

I remixed the leg and lamp shade to allow them to hold 2 LED's, pictured. Got them off Amazon. I had to cut off the loop attachment on top of the LED's to get them to fit.

https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00JSHX4S6/ref=oh_aui_search_detailpage?ie=UTF8&psc=1

I couldn't figure out how jetpuf's design attached the leg to the base, so I modeled some pins into the base and then some hollow cutouts in the bottom of the foot on the leg.

My design software is the basic XYZmaker that comes with the printer, so hopefully the files will work for you.

Finally, I replicated both size shades that jetpuf included, the 130 size being bigger.

Merry Christmas everyone and hope you enjoyed this as much as I did printing and putting in my front window to tease my wife and kids!!

title: Lithophane Lamp for 100 x 100 mm Lithophanes.
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a lithophane lamp I designed. Lithophanes should be 100 x 100 mm with a maximum of 3 mm of depth. The lithophanes slot in and can be moved / replaced by unscrewing the lid. All screw holes use m3 screws. I personally printed my lithophanes with a width between 0.8 and 3 mm.

Some assembly required.

How to assemble:

Note: Print lithophanes and the "Lithodifuser" in white or translucent material to let light through. I recommend printing lithophanes and the "lithodifuser" with 100% infill and everything else with 20% infill.

  1. Print the "Lithoframe" and mount it on top of the "Lithobase" using m3 screws / glue.

  2. Mount the "Lithobase" on top of the "Litholegs" with m3 screws / glue.

  3. Print the light cylinder, and wrap LED strip lights around it unless you choose to choose to use a different lighting method.. There's a mounting hole on the bottom of the light cylinder to attach it to the center of the Lithobase using an m3 screw / nut.

  4. Wire everything up however you want. There's a slot for an on/off switch on one side of the "Lithobase".

  5. Finally, print the "Lithodifuser" and "Litholid" Glue the "Lithodifuser" to the under-side of the "Litholid." Place your lithophanes inside the slots of the "Lithoframe", and screw on the lid using four m3 screws. If you wish to replace "lithodifuser" with something like paper, you can.

Optional: Add LED strip lights to the under-side of the lamp to give out more light.

Here's a link to the on-off switch I used: https://www.banggood.com/5pcs-Black-Push-Button-Mini-Switch-6A-10A-110V-250V-KCD1-101-2Pin-Snap-in-OnOff-Rocker-Switch-p-1096122.html?rmmds=search&cur_warehouse=CN

author: kevinb22

description.text:
This is my first design. I have printed several cases from Thingiverse but have never seen this simple design on the site.

I've bought several cases from Pimoroni and Adafruit for my Raspberry Pi 3 and Pi Zero. Having acquired 20 Pi Zeros for my classes in Papua New Guinea, I had to come up with cases for them.

My favourite laser cut, Pi Zero case is the one I bought from Adafruit (https://www.adafruit.com/product/2883). Using engineering drawings from https://www.raspberrypi.org/documentation/hardware/raspberrypi/mechanical/README.md, I recreated this design for 3D printing.

Some older Pi Zero boards (i.e. most of mine) had soldered tags for the Mini HDMI port that protrudes from the back side, hence the slots on the Pi Zero Base.stl file. Newer Pi Zero and all Pi Zero W boards are flush on the back side and do not need the slots.

I have also produced versions which include the Raspberry Pi logo, from WarHawk8080 (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2545778).

I have printed the case in PLA, PETG and ABS.

The open, honeycomb effect is made by setting top and bottom layers to zero in your slicer and using a 20% honeycomb infill pattern. I like this effect and would assume that this will allow better cooling of the Pi Zero.

The holes are for 3mm bolts as they are usually easier to come by than the 2.5mm that the Pi is sized for. You can either (very carefully) drill out the mounting holes of your Pi Zero to 3.2mm or (as I do) run a 3mm tap through them and screw the nylon bolts through. I have had no problems using either method - but of course accept no responsibility if you break / crack your Pi Zero board, drill a hole in your hand, or bring about the end of the universe as we know it by following my advice.

The SketchUp files are included for any Tinkerers out there.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20% Honeycomb

author: kevinb22

title: E3D Titan Aero + EZABL Mount V2 | CR-10 | CR-10S

description.text:
***UPDATE: I have made a few slight changes to the Extruder, Plate, Rear part (now V2), in that I made the section where the stepper motor mounts with the Titan Aero assembly 1 mm thicker and lowered by 0.5 mm. I found this helped align the gears better since the motor is actually sitting flush with the plate now. I also found that using PLA wasn't adequate for the heat the stepper motor produced since it deformed the bracket enough to cause more misalignment with the gears which saw some backlash. If you weren't having issues with the previous design, then continue using it, otherwise, I have attached Version 2 as well. Enjoy!

This is technically my 2nd attempt in designing a mount specifically for the CR-10/CR-10S printer which allows mounting of an E3D Titan Aero Extruder assembly, TH3D EZABL Sensor, and a 50mm Blower fan.

THIS MOUNT WILL ONLY WORK WITH A 25 MM LENGTH NEMA 17 STEPPER MOTOR. Anything larger will require re-design of this mount as it will clash with the EZABL sensor.

Link is here ->
https://www.omc-stepperonline.com/hybrid-stepper-motor/nema-17-bipolar-18deg-18ncm-255ozin-07a-29v-42x42x25mm-4-wires-17hs10-0704s.html

This mount includes 3 separate components and require some specific constraints when printing as explained below:

Extruder, Plate, Rear
-> Needs to be placed vertically with EZABL hole on build plate
-> No raft needed
-> Supports are optional, but not needed even for the motor mount hole. Some post finishing may be needed depending on specific print settings

Mount, Fan, Duct
-> Highly suggested to place vertically on build plate
-> No raft needed
-> Supports needed for overhang extruded holes

Fan, Blower, Duct
-> Should be placed flush on build plate
-> No raft needed
-> Don't use supports inside the duct area because they are impossible to remove all of the way. Only need support in the slot at the front of the duct where the blower fan will go

My S3D settings are as follows:

Material -> Tianse Blue PLA 1.75 mm

Nozzle Dia. -> 0.40 mm
Extrusion Multiplier -> 0.95
Extrusion Width -> 0.35 mm

Primary Layer Height -> 0.2500 mm
Top/Bottom Solid Layers -> 3
Outline Shells -> 2
Infill -> 10%

Temp (Extruder/Bed) -> 210C/50C

Fan Speed -> 100% after 1st layer

Printing Speed -> 60 mm/s

OFFSETS APPLIED WITH THIS MOUNT FOR CENTERING
(Reference for CR-10/CR-10S)

X_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER -65
Y_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER -20
Z_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 0

Printer:

HICTOP Creality CR-10S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.25 mm

Infill:

10%
There may be need of hole cleanup due to print orientation with or without supports. There are threads modeled into some of the brackets to allow the screws to catch a little easier.

I designed this assembly in Autodesk Fusion 360 and used a STEP file of the Titan Aero Extruder assembly to design around with dimensions measured from the CR-10S extruder carriage for hole placement.

The reason the mount is broken into 3 components is because I wanted there to be flexibility in swapping parts (such as the fan duct) easily without needing to disassemble any of the Titan extruder assembly. So if the fan duct or mounting bracket for the fan isn't suitable, then it may be redesigned with a little more flexibility without needing to re-design all of the components separately.

I have included the step file of the Titan Aero assembly for reference.

title: Rick Sanchez vs. Kiddie Assassins - Rick and Morty

description.text:
Rick Sanchez getting beaten up by two little girls.

The more I thought about it. I guess they're two gymnasts who were hypnotized instead of assassins. Guess I'm committed to 'assassins' now.

Print designed for 0.2 mm layer height. I don't recommend reducing the scale, the tolerances would get really tight. I used various PLA filament brands.

Eyes - White
Outline - Black
Pants - Brown
Belt - Different Brown. I started with black and swapped to brown at 1 mm so it would be slightly darker. Eh...
Mouth - Black, filament swap at 0.4 mm and finish with white.
Tongue - Red
Flesh - Skin, flesh whatever race you'd like
Hair - Teal or whatever appropriate blue you have. This color is also the color of his shirt and the glowing bits of the staff.
Shoes - I used grey, this color is also the metal bits of his staff.

So many tiny bits in his staff, but you can do it! Print extras to replace the parts that get superglued to your fingers!

Parts fit into the outline, use superglue to attach them.

His outline was too big for my printer, so I sliced off the top of the staff and made it separate. One of the blue bits of his staff will bridge the top to the rest of the outline.

Good luck!

title: Monoprice Select Mini V2 Stepper Driver Fan Mount Mod

description.text:
This mod helps prevent the stepper drivers from shutting down do to overheating. If you hear a ticking sound coming from the extruder, it could be due to the driver overheating. When the driver overheats, it faults and shuts off power. The pressure from the filament pins the stepper backwards and then it recovers causing a clicking sound.

Print this bracket, install a 40 mm fan on the driver heat-sink and solder it to the main power header.
