title: Hakko FX-901 Portable Soldering Iron Tip Clamp

description.text:
I dropped my battery powered Hakko soldering iron, and the tip clamp fractured :-(

Fortunately there was enough left for me to see its design, and recreate it in Tinkercad.

UPDATE 24-12-2017 part verified working OK, after some minor redesign. STL updated.

Printer:

HyperCube Evolution

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

A temperature resistant plastic such as PETG or ABS is required. I printed mine in PETG and it's fine.

Supports are pretty much required no matter how you orient the part.. I recommend printing it narrow side to the bed, so that the supports to break off are on a relatively strong section of a part.

The tolerances are very tight and it's almost certain you will need to clean the three clips in the mount to ensure they are clean right angles. You may need to play with filament flow rate (and possibly size percentage) to get the holder printed completely snug with your printer.

There are three things to verify with the clamp, once cleaned up:

  1. the part with three clips fits into the soldering iron and can lock into place.
  2. the bottom of the tip fits properly, with the lower ring of the iron tip fitting snugly inside (see second assembly picture)
  3. the tip itself fits through the hole in the mount. It may be a bit too tight, depending on how tight you might be able to press it in, or you might need to print at a slightly higher size like 100.5 or 101%.

Apart from that it works just like the original clamp.

title: Yellow Ribbon
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
https://fab365.net/items/72

FAB365 is a company that wants to share the joy of 3D printing through minimizing the Disadvantages of 3D printing and maximizing the advantages.

We implement it with three key features.

• Assemble Free

• Support Free

• Size Free

You and enjoy 3D printing new value with stress free!

https://fab365.net

It was made to remember the sad tragedy that should not happen again in Korean history.

However, for each country and society, ribbons are used with different meanings of color.

If you look at its origins, you can find it on the Internet. Since the Internet began, netizens have used Ribbon to express their opinions about specific social issues.
The most representative case is the 'Blue Ribbon Appreciation' movement that took place in 1996 when US Senator Exxon submitted a bill to ban the use of 'abusive language' on the Internet.

Since then, the various colored ribbons that decorate the Internet site and meanings are as follows.

  1. Blue Ribbon : The most representative ribbon used to oppose censorship.
    It is also used as a tool for pet protection.
  2. White Ribbon : A ribbon against a man's violence against a woman.
  3. Black Ribbon : A ribbon used in anarchist and workers' movement.
  4. Gray Ribbon : A ribbon appealing to children with disabilities.
  5. Yellow Ribbon : A ribbon to ban junk mail (indiscriminate advertising mail).
  6. Brown Ribbon : A ribbon to highlight beer drinking rights worldwide.
  7. Red Ribbon : A ribbon emphasizing social education for AIDS.

In addition, according to the color of the ribbon, the medical community uses a colorful ribbon as a symbol to publicize a certain disease to the public and to give a message of hope toward overcoming the disease.

  1. The red ribbon indicates love and passion while informing that HIV / AIDS is an infectious disease caused by blood exchange. And it is an expression of protection, support and understanding of the human rights of HIV / AIDS infected people, emphasizing social education on HIV / AIDS diseases and expressing support for HIV / AIDS patients and all those working for them.

2.The Pink Ribbon has been launched in October every year since it was first created in 1990 by world-renowned cosmetics company, EsterLoader, to promote awareness of breast cancer and the importance of early screening.

  1. Blue Ribbon is being deployed worldwide every September in order to raise awareness of early screening for prostate cancer, which is soaring in Westernized diet. This campaign has spread to many countries around the world since its inception in 1999 by Cap Cure, a nonprofit organization in the UK.

  2. Orange ribbon means starvation, leukemia, multiple sclerosis.

  3. Yellow ribbon means suicide prevention, missing child protection, lung cancer.

  4. Purple Ribbon means animal abuse prevention, ADHD (Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder), and pancreatic cancer.

Therefore, it can be used as a means of expressing your own social expressions.

These ribbons are made in a form that does not require support and can be easily print even for beginners of 3D printers. However, Raft or Brim is required.

Even if you put the clothes pin, you can safely wear it because it does not fall off well.

People who are burdened with putting on clothes can print a little bigger, put them on various rings and attach them to bags or key chains.

The size is 24mm x 40mm x 8.25mm.

remixed_from.title: YADIH - Yet Another Dial Indicator Holder For Replicator

title: And Another Dial Indicator Holder For Replicator 2

description.text:
Another iteration of the dial indicator holder.

I was tempted to use the existing, but decided on the following improvements

  1. Has a simple bore for the stem. Stems are designed to be placed in hardened steel bores or collets as to not pinch the spindle, as a set screw would do.

  2. Adds rear bracket for lug back dial indicator, slotted to allow for limited height adjustment.

  3. Uses 3 magnets to keep the holder as level as possible. Magnets captured from above, so they can't pull out onto the linear rail.
    3a. Magnets press into tapered pockets for easy installation

  4. No need to create a version to support your tolerance, design has allowance for rail to rail spacing variances.

  5. Design has increased beam strength for minimal deflection.

Specifications.

a. Uses a dial indicator with a 0.375" diameter shank, Shars 303-3112 Lug Back, inches
b. Uses 3 magnets .250" dia x .125"
c. Uses 1/4-20 or M6 cap screw, washers and nut

description.text:
The Game Of Tryslmaistan Chess By Jennifer Diane Reitz.
A web published game, described as an analogue of Chess. Played on a triangular board made up of triangles. Each player has three pieces. A third set of three pieces (white) is available for use by either play. On your turn you may move one of your pieces or a white piece. The objective is to remove your opponent's pieces from the board or immobilize them. Unlike chess, your pieces push your opponent's (and White's) pieces around into free spaces. If no space is free, then the pushed piece is removed.

title: Z axis for CNC mini mill
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a model for making a Z axis for a CNC mini mill.
I had a milling table, Dremel, CNC shield and some motors lying around and saw a mini CNC mill in it.
I only needed a Z axis so I made one out of square steel tube (20x20mm). I connected them with 3D printed parts of ABS. It’s purple because I had a lot of that color. The spindles and guiding rod are M8.
Using model “Nema 17 bracket for milling table” I connected the steppers to the milling table. For these brackets please see: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2720575

So with these components I made this mini Mill. Because the table can only move 80 by 80 mm it’s not very big. But of course if you would use a bigger table, you can make the X and Y axis bigger.
As a controller I used an Arduino Uno and a CNC shield with DRV8825 drivers and GRLB python script found on the GitHub (https://github.com/grbl/grbl). In this case I just used universal Gcode sender for sending the Gcode (https://github.com/winder/Universal-G-Code-Sender). The Gcode and paths are created using Inkscape (https://inkscape.org/en/)
First test was on a MDF plate, but worked not so well because I do not have the right milling bit for the Arduino.
Second test was on an acrylic plate, but the milling bit did more melting than milling :-). I suppose I had to use a cooling liquid.
Third test was on an aluminum plate and that worked better except that my mini Dremel bit flexed a bit during milling.
The fourth test was milling a PCB and it worked but I have to improve my Gcode.
So the mini mill works very well. The motors didn’t skip any steps due to EMF frequencies coming of the Dremel brushed motor. I did use a DIY mains filter for it. If you are interested in this mains filter feel free to ask. As a backup I even had a 1:1 1KVA transformer ready, but I didn’t need it.
I didn’t use end switches because the can cause a lot of EMF issues. Also I didn’t shield anything, so less is more :-)
For micro stepping I had to settle on 4 micro steps for the X and Y motor avoiding.

If you have any questions feel free to ask :-)
